commit_message:
Fix documentation warnings from sphinx

Many of the documentation pages in the security role aren't
meant to be displayed in a table of contents, and this was generating
lots of warnings in the sphinx output. This patch sets the :orphan:
tag on any pages that shouldn't appear inside a toctree.

Change-Id: I1b1f95e35946731ab1122bb1835bbd448b356acc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security refs/changes/39/329139/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add detection plugin for enabling ovs plugin

This plugin detects the ovs exsistance and writes the configurations to
ovs.yaml in conf.d directory. The configurations will be fetched from the
neutron configuration file.

Change-Id: I0b469276231764f6c854a6b0149cd3a4269ac4a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/94/319094/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (C) Copyright 2015-2016 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP import ConfigParser import grp import logging import os import psutil import monasca_setup.agent_config import monasca_setup.detection log = logging.getLogger(__name__) # Maximum time to wait before updating neutron router cache(in seconds) neutron_refresh = 60 * 60 * 4 # Four hours # Directory to use for metric caches cache_dir = "/dev/shm" # Location of the open vswitch command ovs_cmd = "sudo /usr/bin/ovs-vsctl" # If set, will submit network metrics in bits network_use_bits = True class Ovs(monasca_setup.detection.Plugin): """Detect OVS daemons and setup configuration to monitor """ def _detect(self): # Detect Agent's OS username by getting the group owner of confg file try: gid = os.stat('/etc/monasca/agent/agent.yaml').st_gid self.agent_user = grp.getgrgid(gid)[0] except OSError: self.agent_user = None # Try to detect the location of the Neutron configuration file. # Walk through the list of processes, searching for 'neutron' # process with 'neutron.conf' inside one of the parameters. neutron_conf = None for proc in psutil.process_iter(): try: cmd = proc.cmdline() if len(cmd) > 2 and 'python' in cmd[0] and 'neutron' in cmd[1]: conf_indexes = [cmd.index(y) for y in cmd if 'neutron.conf' in y] if not conf_indexes: continue param = conf_indexes[0] if '=' in cmd[param]: neutron_conf = cmd[param].split('=')[1] else: neutron_conf = cmd[param] except (IOError, psutil.NoSuchProcess): # Process has already terminated, ignore continue if (neutron_conf is not None and os.path.isfile(neutron_conf)): self.available = True self.neutron_conf = neutron_conf def build_config(self): """Build the config as a Plugins object and return. """ config = monasca_setup.agent_config.Plugins() if self.dependencies_installed(): neutron_cfg = ConfigParser.SafeConfigParser() log.info("\tUsing neutron configuration file {0}".format(self.neutron_conf)) neutron_cfg.read(self.neutron_conf) # Which configuration options are needed for the plugin YAML? # Use a dict so that they can be renamed later if necessary cfg_needed = {'admin_user': 'admin_user', 'admin_password': 'admin_password', 'admin_tenant_name': 'admin_tenant_name'} cfg_section = 'keystone_authtoken' # Handle Devstack's slightly different neutron.conf names if(neutron_cfg.has_option(cfg_section, 'username') and neutron_cfg.has_option(cfg_section, 'password') and neutron_cfg.has_option(cfg_section, 'project_name')): cfg_needed = {'admin_user': 'username', 'admin_password': 'password', 'admin_tenant_name': 'project_name'} # Start with plugin-specific configuration parameters init_config = {'cache_dir': cache_dir, 'neutron_refresh': neutron_refresh, 'ovs_cmd': ovs_cmd, 'network_use_bits': network_use_bits} for option in cfg_needed: init_config[option] = neutron_cfg.get(cfg_section, cfg_needed[option]) # Create an identity URI (again, slightly different for Devstack) if neutron_cfg.has_option(cfg_section, 'auth_url'): init_config['identity_uri'] = "{0}/v2.0".format(neutron_cfg.get(cfg_section, 'auth_url')) else: init_config['identity_uri'] = "{0}/v2.0".format(neutron_cfg.get(cfg_section, 'identity_uri')) # Create an region_name (again, slightly different for Devstack) if neutron_cfg.has_option('service_auth', 'region'): init_config['region_name'] = "{0}".format(neutron_cfg.get('service_auth', 'region')) else: init_config['region_name'] = "{0}".format(neutron_cfg.get('nova', 'region_name')) # Handle monasca-setup detection arguments, which take precedence if self.args: for arg in self.args: init_config[arg] = self.literal_eval(self.args[arg]) config['ovs'] = {'init_config': init_config, 'instances': {}} return config def dependencies_installed(self): try: import json import monasca_agent.collector.virt.inspector import time except ImportError: log.warn("\tDependencies not satisfied; plugin not configured.") return False if os.path.isdir(cache_dir) is False: log.warn("\tCache directory {} not found;" + " plugin not configured.".format(cache_dir)) return False return True

commit_message:
Convert Keystone to HostNetwork=False, Fix bootstrap.

This sets up Keystone as an internal service that bootstraps.

I decided that the public and internal Keystone were worth
running as separate services (e.g. you wouldn't expose the admin
with the same LB as the public)

Change-Id: I25d83abe948393f99aa679e200a47cda385ca619
Partially-implements: blueprint kolla-kubernetes-service-discovery
Partially-implements: blueprint remove-net-hostremove-net-host
Co-authored-by: Ryan Hallisey <rhallise@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Implemented vSwitch metrics for the router and dhcp ports

Implemented the below metrics
vswitch.out_bytes
vswitch.in_bytes
vswitch.in_bits
vswitch.out_bits
vswitch.out_packets
vswitch.in_dropped
vswitch.out_dropped
vswitch.in_errors
vswitch.out_errors
vswitch.in_packets

vswitch.out_bytes_sec
vswitch.in_bytes_sec
vswitch.out_bits_sec
vswitch.in_bits_sec
vswitch.out_packets_sec
vswitch.in_dropped_sec
vswitch.out_dropped_sec
vswitch.in_errors_sec
vswitch.out_errors_sec
vswitch.in_packets_sec

Co-Authored-By: Alok Kumar Maurya <alok-kumar.maurya@hp.com>
Change-Id: Ifc45fe49e29b64d693fee015ad84fac523af6682
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/00/322300/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## Per-ovs port Metrics | Name | Description | | --------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | vswitch.port.transmit.bytes | Bytes transmitted on port | | vswitch.port.receive.bytes | Bytes received on port | | vswitch.port.transmit.packets | Packets transmitted on port | | vswitch.port.receive.packets | Packets received on port | | vswitch.port.transmit.dropped | Drops transmitted on port | | vswitch.port.receive.dropped | Drops received on port | | vswitch.port.transmit.error | Errors transmitted on port | | vswitch.port.receive.error | Errors received on port | | vswitch.port.transmit.util | Utilization of transmitted port | | vswitch.port.receive.util | Utilization of received port | ## OVS Port Metric Dimensions | Dimension Name | Customer Value | Operations Value | | -------------- | -------------------------- | --------------------------- | | hostname | (N/A) | hostname hosting the ports | | resource_id | resource ID of port | neutron port id of the port | | service | "networking" | "networking" | | component | "ovs" | "ovs" | | tenant_id | (N/A) | project owner of the router |

commit_message:
Add cpu.utilization_norm_perc metric to libvirt

This metric represents the virtual cpu utilization
as an aggregate of the virtual cores. (normalized to 0-100%)

Change-Id: I5f884668e3994e5d4e71acc9750bbe72a3bbf2f3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/28/326728/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cpu_info = insp.inspect_cpus(inst) cpu_diff = cpu_info.time - metric_cache[inst_name]['cpu.time']['value'] 'value': cpu_info.time} self.gauge('vcpu.utilization_perc', int(round(rate / cpu_info.number, 0)), dimensions=dims_customer, delegated_tenant=instance_cache.get(inst_name)['tenant_id'], hostname=instance_cache.get(inst_name)['hostname'])

commit_message:
Add more compute cpu metrics

This includes:
cpu.idle_time
cpu.wait_time
cpu.user_time
cpu.system_time
cpu.frequency_mhz
cpu.percent

Change-Id: Ib4b6ca2ba3b3a4d660c7e35bda9a7952bf7764d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/62/326762/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (C) Copyright 2015-2016 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LPimport re import subprocess cpu_times = psutil.cpu_times(percpu=False) lscpu_command = subprocess.Popen('lscpu', stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE) lscpu_output = lscpu_command.communicate()[0].decode(encoding='UTF-8') cpu_freq_output = re.search("(CPU MHz:.*?(\d+\.\d+)\nB)", lscpu_output) cpu_freq = float(cpu_freq_output.group(2)) cpu_times.idle, cpu_times.iowait, (cpu_times.user + cpu_times.nice), (cpu_times.system + cpu_times.irq + cpu_times.softirq), cpu_freq, def _format_results(self, us, sy, wa, idle, st, idle_ns, wa_ns, us_ns, sy_ns, cpu_freq, dimensions, instance): 'cpu.stolen_perc': st, 'cpu.idle_time_ns': idle_ns, 'cpu.wait_time_ns': wa_ns, 'cpu.user_time_ns': us_ns, 'cpu.system_time_ns': sy_ns, 'cpu.frequency_MHz': cpu_freq}
deleted_lines: # (C) Copyright 2015 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP def _format_results(self, us, sy, wa, idle, st, dimensions, instance): 'cpu.stolen_perc': st}

commit_message:
workaround to fix ambari start on centos7

Change-Id: I1a0383861db50ae5136e8dff9de4119b566606f1
Closes-bug: 1579187
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/16/324416/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: redirect_file = "/tmp/%s" % uuidutils.generate_uuid() sudo("service ambari-server start >{rfile} && " "cat {rfile} && rm {rfile}".format(rfile=redirect_file))

subject: Tidy of item 5 of the vulnerability:managed tag
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-01 23:57:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/8b33c9d4978e9dfdfc0feccf72b0a4aa5cc4ec11', 'message': "Tidy of item 5 of the vulnerability:managed tag

There seems to be significant confusion in the community around who
can do a audit, review, or threat analysis.  The term third party
seems to confuse atleast the designate team, who has done a company
internal threat analysis.  Does this constitute a third party?  I'd
say so since it was done by security experts which are typically
isolated from internal company politics.

Further, the security team can't scale to handle TA for the big
tent, so let the projects themselves do a threat analysis, and provide
final signature authority to an impartial third party who, if they
are security experts I've met, protect their reputation by doing
a thourough job of validating other people's audits, reviews, or
threat analysis.

Change-Id: Ia28c2eb3b88a6e197841bb22c49fd1ac83f10871
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-27 17:24:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/9e90bf9949afba655c0a6664f498fdb89dc71bc3', 'message': "Tidy of item 5 of the vulnerability:managed tag

can do a audit, review, or threat analysis.  The term third party
seems to confuse atleast the designate team, who has done a company
internal threat analysis.  Does this constitute a third party?  I'd
say so since it was done by security experts which are typically
isolated from internal company politics.

Further, the security team can't scale to handle TA for the big
tent, so let the projects themselves do a threat analysis, and provide
final signature authority to an impartial third party who, if they
are security experts I've met, protect their reputation by doing
a thourough job of validating other people's audits, reviews, or
threat analysis.

Change-Id: Ia28c2eb3b88a6e197841bb22c49fd1ac83f10871
Depends-On: I2e2dd8a5fa68b80868e9d6fde8916a9555f4dcab
"}]
commit_message:
Tidy of item 5 of the vulnerability:managed tag

There seems to be significant confusion in the community around who
can do a audit, review, or threat analysis.  The term third party
seems to confuse atleast the designate team, who has done a company
internal threat analysis.  Does this constitute a third party?  I'd
say so since it was done by security experts which are typically
isolated from internal company politics.

Further, the security team can't scale to handle TA for the big
tent, so let the projects themselves do a threat analysis, and provide
final signature authority to an impartial third party who, if they
are security experts I've met, protect their reputation by doing
a thourough job of validating other people's audits, reviews, or
threat analysis.

Change-Id: Ia28c2eb3b88a6e197841bb22c49fd1ac83f10871
Depends-On: I2e2dd8a5fa68b80868e9d6fde8916a9555f4dcab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/98/300698/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 5. The deliverable's repos should undergo a review, audit, or threat analysis looking for obvious signs of insecure design or risky implementation which could imply a large number of future vulnerability reports. The review, audit, or threat analysis may be done by the project team itself or an impartial third party. In the event the project team involved in the tagging peforms the review, audit, or threat analysis, the results must be validated by a third party in public fashion. The VMT doesn't stipulate which third party would perform this review or validation; for example members of the OpenStack Security other third party including sponsoring companies of a project may offer assistance. As much as anything this is a measure to keep the VMT's workload down, since it is by necessity a group of constrained size and some of its processes simply can't be scaled safely.
deleted_lines: 5. The deliverable's repos should undergo a third-party review, audit, or threat analysis looking for obvious signs of insecure design or risky implementation which could imply a large number of future vulnerability reports. As much as anything this is a measure to keep the VMT's workload down, since it is by necessity a group of constrained size and some of its processes simply can't be scaled safely. The VMT doesn't stipulate who would actually perform this review; for example members of the OpenStack Security other third party may offer assistance.

commit_message:
Change device_driver to the neutron LBaasV2 version

The HaproxyNSDriver should be LBaasV2 compatible. In the
puppet-neutron, the device_driver is set to neutron
LBaasV1
This fix will change the default value of the device
drive to correspond to neutron LBaasV2, and will
enable V2 and disable V1.

Change-Id: I9301960e41d4f16845c180992c89d77937ac168f
Partial-Bug: #1581876

commit_message:
Add logic for volume.backend_names

Tempest has a config option for backend_names under
volume_group, but it is not set when devstack is run and
multiple backends are detected. This patch sets the tempest
CONF for volume.backend_names.

Change-Id: I93e9d519e1b8dc3bf485b44398affbf19b520261
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/10/329210/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local be_list if [ $i -eq 1 ]; then be_list="$be_name" else be_list="$be_list, $be_name" fi iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG volume "backend_names" "$be_list"

Define v2 endpoints_client as libarry

then this patch makes the client as a library.

commit_message:
tripleo.sh support updating and checking deployed overcloud

Adds initial support for overcloud updates via the --overcloud-update option
which will update an already deployed overcloud heat stack.

Optionally we can check the before/after resources and prove that nothing
changed during the updates (no resources replaced, added or deleted) by
passing --enable-check.  In a future patch this will be enhanced to
allow for expecting specific changes, e.g via a regex or list.

Change-Id: Ie35360de617d0bbb1fa55c0f10956e6e669dda8d
(cherry picked from commit e078ab9af266cff07fd8abca72865f5d5f14ef27)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/54/329654/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo " --overcloud-update -- Update a deployed overcloud." echo " --enable-check -- Enable checks on update." -l,help,repo-setup,delorean-setup,delorean-build,undercloud,overcloud-images,register-nodes,introspect-nodes,flavors,overcloud-deploy,overcloud-update,overcloud-delete,use-containers,overcloud-pingtest,all,enable-check \OVERCLOUD_UPDATE=${OVERCLOUD_UPDATE:-""} OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_RM_FILES=${OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_RM_FILES:-"1"} OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_ARGS=${OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_ARGS:-"$OVERCLOUD_DEPLOY_ARGS"} OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_CHECK=${OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_CHECK:-} --enable-check) OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_CHECK="1"; shift 1;; --overcloud-update) OVERCLOUD_UPDATE="1"; shift 1;; log "Overcloud create started." log "Overcloud create - DONE." } function overcloud_update { # Force use of --templates if [[ ! $OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_ARGS =~ --templates ]]; then OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_ARGS="$OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_ARGS --templates" fi stackrc_check if heat stack-show "$OVERCLOUD_NAME" | grep "stack_status " | egrep "(CREATE|UPDATE)_COMPLETE"; then FILE_PREFIX=$(date "+overcloud-update-resources-%s") BEFORE_FILE="/tmp/${FILE_PREFIX}-before.txt" AFTER_FILE="/tmp/${FILE_PREFIX}-after.txt" # This is an update, so if enabled, compare the before/after resource lists if [ ! -z "$OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_CHECK" ]; then heat resource-list -n5 overcloud | awk '{print $2, $4, $6}' | sort > $BEFORE_FILE fi log "Overcloud update started." openstack overcloud deploy $OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_ARGS log "Overcloud update - DONE." if [ ! -z "$OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_CHECK" ]; then heat resource-list -n5 overcloud | awk '{print $2, $4, $6}' | sort > $AFTER_FILE diff_rsrc=$(diff $BEFORE_FILE $AFTER_FILE) if [ ! -z "$diff_rsrc" ]; then log "Overcloud update - Completed but unexpected resource differences: $diff_rsrc" exit 1 fi fi log "Overcloud update - DONE." if [[ $OVERCLOUD_UPDATE_RM_FILES == 1 ]]; then rm -f $BEFORE_FILE $AFTER_FILE fi else log "Overcloud FAILED - No stack $OVERCLOUD_NAME." exit 1 fiif [ "$OVERCLOUD_UPDATE" = 1 ]; then overcloud_update fi

commit_message:
Make endpoints_client use **kwargs

As we discussed on
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-July/068864.html
All http POST/PUT methods need to contain **kwargs as their arguments.
This patch makes endpoints_client use **kwargs.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: If0f4822cbcd6aed45d2351e11a2d84a1be6f5bb2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/96/329196/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: """Create an endpoint for service.""" post_body = { 'service_id': service_id, 'region': region_id, 'publicurl': kwargs.get('publicurl'), 'adminurl': kwargs.get('adminurl'), 'internalurl': kwargs.get('internalurl') } post_body = json.dumps({'endpoint': post_body})

added_lines: def test_check_container(self): self.dw.params['name'] = 'test_container' expect_data = {'Command': 'test_cmd', 'Created': 1612574844, 'Id': 'test_id', 'Image': 'busybox:buildroot-2014.02', 'Names': ['/test_container'], 'Ports': [], 'Status': 'Up 1 seconds'} self.dw.dc.containers = mock.MagicMock(return_value=[expect_data]) resp_data = self.dw.check_container() self.assertEqual(expect_data, resp_data) self.assertFalse(self.dw.changed) def test_start_container_without_pull(self): self.dw.params = dict( image='myregistrydomain.com:5000/ubuntu:16.04', name='new_test_container', detach = 'True', auth_username='fake_user', auth_password='fake_psw', auth_registry='myrepo/myapp', auth_email='fake_mail@foogle.com') fake_images = [ {'Created': 1462317178, 'Labels': {}, 'VirtualSize': 120759015, 'ParentId': '','RepoTags': ['ubuntu:16.04'], 'RepoDigests': None, 'Id': 'sha256:c5f1cf30', 'Size': 120759015}, {'Created': 1461802380, 'Labels': {}, 'VirtualSize': 403096303, 'ParentId': '', 'RepoTags': ['centos:7.0'], 'RepoDigests': None, 'Id': 'sha256:336a6', 'Size': 403096303}] fake_containers = [ {'Command': '/bin/bash', 'Created': 1463578194, 'Status': 'Up 23 hours', 'HostConfig': {'NetworkMode': 'default'}, 'Id': 'e40d8e7187', 'Image': 'ubuntu', 'ImageID': 'sha256:c5f1cf30', 'Labels': {}, 'Names': ['/test_container']} ] self.dw.dc.images = mock.MagicMock(return_value=fake_images) self.dw.dc.containers = mock.MagicMock() self.dw.dc.containers.side_effect = [fake_containers[0].update({ 'Name': '/test_container', fake_containers[0].update({ 'Name': '/new_test_container', 'Status': 'Up 2 seconds'} ] self.dw.check_container_differs=mock.MagicMock(return_value=False) self.dw.create_container=mock.magicMock(return_value=fake_containers[0].update({'Name': '/new_test_container', u'Status': u'Up 2 seconds'})) self.dw.create_containee.assert_called_once_with()

commit_message:
Fix retype from non-repl to repl type in Pure drivers

You could make it work if you set the migration policy, but the short
version would fail in the driver.

This was missed by unit tests due to over-zealous mocking… that has also
been corrected.

Change-Id: I91ac3ff21ed8619d03fc3c00e5ec76fd280c7713
Closes-Bug: #1585021
(cherry picked from commit b208280a6be423058ea97b21c6ea4fa622d2f745)

commit_message:
Return generated attrubutes as a dict not a string

Generated attributes should be returned not as a string but as a
dict which defines the 'hidden' attribute with the generated value.

Change-Id: I1bf7a951c1299e85baf3ed0be62b36b0a329150c
Closes-Bug: #1592083

commit_message:
Make IPAM segment aware on port update

With this change, Neutron will perform late port binding in the case
where no IPs were assigned on port create (because no host binding was
provided then).  It will filter subnets based on the binding host
provider on port update.

Change-Id: I90046136e495f3612bbe213483aba2605c66f787
Partially-Implements: blueprint routed-networks

commit_message:
Use pre-defined inputs in TestGetHashPrefixAndSuffix

Running tests currently requires a read access on swift.conf,
which is often not available to unprivileged users. In fact,
the file may not even be present on the development system.

This is the first step to get tests to use only the data
supplied with the tree.

Change-Id: Ia63904b6c32293ca6fb38641cea514533259d909

commit_message:
Missing call to super(xxx, self).__init__()

The __init__() routine of NeutronDbPluginV2 is missing the call to
super(xxx, self).__init__() which is preventing other __init__()
routines from being run.  This is causing an exception in networking-ovn
when attempting to use QoS.

Change-Id: I369e8399f213fc300e70c4cce7ca0ff5c9f1e078
Closes-Bug: #1584204
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/44/319444/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix for status-set race - related to bug 1588462

This change fixes the obvious race for a status_set() between
check_optional_interfaces() and assess_status() as the later calls the former
which calls status_set(), returns the status, which is then potentially set
again by the assess_status() function.  This cleans up the code so that only a
single status_set() is performed when calling assess_status().

Change-Id: Ie37a4d98de9c5e7bd26304e096796ce6287ea52b
Related-Bug:#1588462
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-cloud-controller refs/changes/19/329219/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix errors in ``set/unset flavor`` unit tests

1. We should assert flavor.set_keys() is called correctly
   or not called in ``set flavor`` unit tests.

2. Commit c7e6973ff50ff84af9ad55f7bdaeeea83ae40f0b from me
   removed test_flavor_unset_no_project which used to test
   if --project was specified as '', and assert CommandError
   was raised, which is incorrect. So I removed it. But after
   looking into the code, I think we should not remove it,
   but specify nothing after --project, and assert
   ParserException was raised. So in this patch, we fix it
   as so.

   ('--project', '') --> ('--project')
   assert CommandError --> assert ParserException

Change-Id: Ifd33c72d5b7581aaabffb09e9b5e38ecc67e18c0

commit_message:
Fix post jobs

Post jobs cannot currently use constraints, they fail like
http://logs.openstack.org/80/80745bc1c5c1fc78172a853a6370661261f8cf23/post/networking-ovn-upstream-translation-update/229e4f3/

Use normal install command for all environments that might be used in
post jobs (venv, releasenotes, cover).

Change-Id: I9576e440f22f0a15366961d765df88b0120ac7a6

commit_message:
Add transport_url and rpc_response_timeout for oslo.messaging

This commit adds the transport_url parameters for oslo.messaging. The
url is of the form:

  transport://user:pass@host1:port[,hostN:portN]/virtual_host

Where the transport scheme specifies the rpc or notification backend
as one of rabbit, amqp, zmq, etc. Oslo.messaging is deprecating the
host, port, and auth configuration options [1]. All drivers will get
these options via the transport_url.

The rpc_response_timeout was also included because it is used
explicitly in oslo.messaging, and it's being set in some deployment
tools. So by using the oslo::messaging resource in nova, it will
break those deployment tools. So a commit to take this into use is
needed on that side.

This patch:
* use oslo::messaging::default resource
* use oslo::messaging::notifications resource
* add parameters for transport_url(s)
* add parameter for rpc_response_timeout
* update spec tests
* add feature release note

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/317285/

Change-Id: I961e7b4f061efef3ee988e698b41a7241afb4053
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/18/321818/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add temporary test_proxy_base2

In order to get the resource2 refactors moving along, the
test_proxy_base code currently points to "resource" in a lot of the
strings that get passed into various mock points. This temporarily adds
a second test_proxy_base alongside it so that we can have this refactor
move along in a per-service way. Otherwise we'd have to do one mass
change, which is far too big.

FWIW, this was originally included in the compute refactor change but
I'm splitting it out so that multiple changes can be done in parallel.

Change-Id: I7282a2413bbfd8c0e97e9b13d8141ebb30834591

expected_result="result", **kwargs): the_kwargs = {"x": 1, "y": 2, "z": 3} method_kwargs = kwargs.pop("method_kwargs", the_kwargs) expected_args = [resource_type] expected_kwargs = kwargs.pop("expected_kwargs", the_kwargs) self._verify2(mock_method, test_method, expected_result=expected_result, method_kwargs=method_kwargs, expected_args=expected_args, expected_kwargs=expected_kwargs, **kwargs) def verify_delete(self, test_method, resource_type, ignore, input_path_args=None, expected_path_args=None, method_kwargs=None, expected_args=None, expected_kwargs=None, mock_method="openstack.proxy2.BaseProxy._delete"): method_args = ["resource_or_id"] method_kwargs = method_kwargs or {} method_kwargs["ignore_missing"] = ignore if isinstance(input_path_args, dict): for key in input_path_args: method_kwargs[key] = input_path_args[key] elif isinstance(input_path_args, list): method_args = input_path_args expected_kwargs = expected_kwargs or {} expected_kwargs["ignore_missing"] = ignore if expected_path_args: expected_kwargs.update(expected_path_args) expected_args = expected_args or [resource_type, "resource_or_id"] self._verify2(mock_method, test_method, method_args=method_args, method_kwargs=method_kwargs, expected_args=expected_args, expected_kwargs=expected_kwargs) def verify_get(self, test_method, resource_type, value=None, args=None, mock_method="openstack.proxy2.BaseProxy._get", ignore_value=False, **kwargs): the_value = value if value is None: the_value = [] if ignore_value else ["value"] expected_args = kwargs.pop("expected_args", []) expected_kwargs = kwargs.pop("expected_kwargs", {}) method_kwargs = kwargs.pop("method_kwargs", kwargs) if args: expected_kwargs["args"] = args if kwargs: expected_kwargs["path_args"] = kwargs if not expected_args: expected_args = [resource_type] + the_value self._verify2(mock_method, test_method, method_args=the_value, method_kwargs=method_kwargs or {}, expected_args=expected_args, expected_kwargs=expected_kwargs) def verify_head(self, test_method, resource_type, mock_method="openstack.proxy2.BaseProxy._head", value=None, **kwargs): the_value = [value] if value is not None else [] expected_kwargs = {"path_args": kwargs} if kwargs else {} self._verify2(mock_method, test_method, method_args=the_value, method_kwargs=kwargs, expected_args=[resource_type] + the_value, expected_kwargs=expected_kwargs) def verify_find(self, test_method, resource_type, value=None, mock_method="openstack.proxy2.BaseProxy._find", path_args=None, **kwargs): method_args = value or ["name_or_id"] expected_kwargs = {} self._add_path_args_for_verify(path_args, method_args, expected_kwargs, value=value) # TODO(briancurtin): if sub-tests worked in this mess of # test dependencies, the following would be a lot easier to work with. expected_kwargs["ignore_missing"] = False self._verify2(mock_method, test_method, method_args=method_args + [False], expected_args=[resource_type, "name_or_id"], expected_kwargs=expected_kwargs, expected_result="result", **kwargs) expected_kwargs["ignore_missing"] = True self._verify2(mock_method, test_method, method_args=method_args + [True], expected_args=[resource_type, "name_or_id"], expected_kwargs=expected_kwargs, expected_result="result", **kwargs) def verify_list(self, test_method, resource_type, paginated=False, mock_method="openstack.proxy2.BaseProxy._list", **kwargs): expected_kwargs = kwargs.pop("expected_kwargs", {}) expected_kwargs.update({"paginated": paginated}) method_kwargs = kwargs.pop("method_kwargs", {}) self._verify2(mock_method, test_method, method_kwargs=method_kwargs, expected_args=[resource_type], expected_kwargs=expected_kwargs, expected_result=["result"], **kwargs) def verify_list_no_kwargs(self, test_method, resource_type, paginated=False, mock_method="openstack.proxy2.BaseProxy._list"): self._verify2(mock_method, test_method, method_kwargs={}, expected_args=[resource_type], expected_kwargs={"paginated": paginated}, expected_result=["result"]) def verify_update(self, test_method, resource_type, value=None, mock_method="openstack.proxy2.BaseProxy._update", expected_result="result", path_args=None, **kwargs): method_args = value or ["resource_or_id"] method_kwargs = {"x": 1, "y": 2, "z": 3} expected_args = kwargs.pop("expected_args", ["resource_or_id"]) expected_kwargs = method_kwargs.copy() self._add_path_args_for_verify(path_args, method_args, expected_kwargs, value=value) self._verify2(mock_method, test_method, expected_result=expected_result, method_args=method_args, method_kwargs=method_kwargs, expected_args=[resource_type] + expected_args, expected_kwargs=expected_kwargs, **kwargs) def verify_wait_for_status( self, test_method, mock_method="openstack.resource2.wait_for_status", **kwargs): self._verify(mock_method, test_method, **kwargs)

subject: Updates projects.yaml to indicate type:service only if a REST API is provided
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-16 21:19:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/a7cff24a7dcf367eca80e1326c1bc081252b132b', 'message': 'Updates projects.yaml to indicate service: only if a REST API is provided

As we look towards improving the docs experience for devs consuming
OpenStack Services through standard REST APIs (as noted one of the most
important reasons for OpenStack adoption in the User Survey), I want to
begin standardizing REST API docs location and findability.

If I couldn't find REST API docs for a service, I removed the service: line.

If the REST API docs would not be published on an openstack.org site, such
as EC2 compatibility, I removed the service: line.

In the case of TripleO, it's possible that the tuskar REST API would need
to be documented, and the service: line should remain for TripleO.

For collective projects like Telemetry, there may be need for multiple
REST API docs source and publication.

This first pass should be reviewed for "is there a REST API for this service?"

It's possible we'll need to add a description: line to say what the project
aims to provide, if the projec's mission is other than providing a REST API
service.

Change-Id: I614d065893d1c4dd2e527f2b988993b284e6d02c

commit_message:
Updates projects.yaml to indicate type:service only if a REST API is provided

As we look towards improving the docs experience for devs consuming
OpenStack Services through standard REST APIs (as noted one of the most
mentioned reasons for OpenStack adoption in the User Survey[1]), I want to
begin standardizing REST API docs location and findability.

For collective projects like Telemetry, there may be need for multiple
REST API docs source and publication. The way their repos are set up,
there are two type:service lines. However in the case of neutron projects,
there is only one type:service even though there are multiple REST APIs (5 of
them? I'm not sure.)

This first pass should be reviewed for "is there a REST API for this service?"

If we don't indicate which projects publish a REST API we cannot provide
a single developer.openstack.org site with all OpenStack REST APIs documented.

1. page 9 http://www.openstack.org/assets/survey/April-2016-User-Survey-Report.pdf
Change-Id: I614d065893d1c4dd2e527f2b988993b284e6d02c

commit_message:
Commiting a cookie cutter module sync set of files

This module had pre-existing content which is not the
methodology puppet-openstack community advises.

This commit takes the content from their new-module
documentation and commits it to this repo as a marker
to where the module should have started.

The previous history is being kept for preservation
and will be migrated into upcoming commits to establish
a developmental history based on the cookiecutter and
msync foundation as documented by the puppet openstack
community.

Change-Id: I91def5bf63b88b22153ebefd4018f1252f4b5d2b
Signed-off-by: Dan Radez <dradez@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove pip_lock_down dependency

The pip_install and pip_lock_down roles have been merged.

Remove pip_lock_down from the role's meta dependencies and test
requirements.

Change-Id: I537994fc2f4c1132938837a7d5428db4f5dc282a

commit_message:
networking-bagpipe 4.0.0 (mitaka) release

This is the very first release of the subproject. The version is not
1.0.0 because the team wants to stay in sync with networking-bgpvpn in
terms of versioning.

commit_message:
Make cleanup remove restarting/exited containers

If we have bug in contianer or it simplt somehow ended up in Exited
state, cleanup doesn't flush it. It also means it doesn't flush volumes
and that might cause an dirty env.

Closes-Bug: #1587344
Change-Id: Ib5705992500ce7efdc66509df61c381bd33d1954
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/11/329511/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-12 13:45:08.000000000', 'files': ['services/keystone/keystone-pod.yml.j2', 'bootstrap/keystone/keystone-job.yml.j2.rej', 'bootstrap/keystone/keystone-job.yml.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/16af7e671c57a38093f16eaf8510b21187462885', 'message': "The Keystone bootstrap job need to run a db sync

The Keystone bootstrap job was not running a database sync.
It was creating the users, passwords, and Keystone endpoints.

The bootstrap job was also failing to find /var/log/kolla/keystone.
We need to mount in /var/log/kolla/keystone so that the container
can change its permissions.

Jenkins wasn't verifiing this patch. Moving the patch here.

Closes-bug: #1589284

commit_message:
The Keystone bootstrap job need to run a db sync

The Keystone bootstrap job was not running a database sync.
It was creating the users, passwords, and Keystone endpoints.

The bootstrap job was also failing to find /var/log/kolla/keystone.
We need to mount in /var/log/kolla/keystone so that the container
can change its permissions.

Jenkins wasn't verifiing this patch. Moving the patch here.

Change-Id: Ia6550975a150ef412a4e8f4898f5f958bd842b00
Partially-implements: blueprint openstack-services
Closes-bug: #1589285
Closes-bug: #1589284
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes refs/changes/31/328731/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: name: keystone-bootstrap volumeMounts: - mountPath: {{ container_config_directory }} name: keystone-config readOnly: true - mountPath: /var/log/kolla/keystone name: kolla-logs env: - name: KOLLA_BOOTSTRAP value: "" - name: KOLLA_CONFIG_STRATEGY value: "{{ config_strategy }}" - image: "{{ keystone_image_full }}" - mountPath: /var/log/kolla/keystone
deleted_lines: - mountPath: /var/log/kolla name: kolla-logs - mountPath: /var/log/kolla name: kolla-logs - mountPath: /var/log/kolla - name: KOLLA_KUBERNETES_BOOTSTRAP value: "" - name: ETCD_HOST value: "{{ etcd_ip_address }}" - name: ETCD_PORT value: "{{ etcd_port }}"

commit_message:
Remove migrated "unauthed" functional tests

These tests are moved to the designate-tempest-plugin in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/329187/

Change-Id: I399d4018f78d59c61c5bd5cc3be57bf678a3a75b
Depends-On: I9752685afccee5dcd009f76b5242fd6f12f0fc37

deleted_lines: """ Copyright 2015 Rackspace Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. """ from tempest_lib import exceptions from functionaltests.common import datagen from functionaltests.common import utils from functionaltests.api.v2.base import DesignateV2Test from functionaltests.api.v2.clients.recordset_client import RecordsetClient from functionaltests.api.v2.clients.zone_client import ZoneClient @utils.parameterized_class class RecordsetTest(DesignateV2Test): def setUp(self): super(RecordsetTest, self).setUp() self.increase_quotas(user='default') self.ensure_tld_exists('com') resp, self.zone = ZoneClient.as_user('default').post_zone( datagen.random_zone_data()) ZoneClient.as_user('default').wait_for_zone(self.zone.id) self.client = RecordsetClient.as_user('default', with_token=False) def tearDown(self): super(RecordsetTest, self).tearDown() resp, self.zone = ZoneClient.as_user('default').delete_zone( self.zone.id) def test_create_a_recordset(self): post_model = datagen.random_a_recordset(self.zone.name) self.assertRaises( exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.post_recordset, self.zone.id, post_model) def test_get_fake_recordset(self): self.assertRaises( exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.get_recordset, self.zone.id, 'junk') def test_get_existing_recordset(self): post_model = datagen.random_a_recordset(self.zone.name) resp, resp_model = RecordsetClient.as_user('default') \ .post_recordset(self.zone.id, post_model) self.assertRaises( exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.get_recordset, self.zone.id, resp_model.id) def test_list_recordsets(self): self.assertRaises( exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.list_recordsets, self.zone.id) def test_update_fake_recordset(self): put_model = datagen.random_a_recordset(self.zone.name) self.assertRaises( exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.put_recordset, self.zone.id, 'junk', put_model) def test_update_existing_recordset(self): post_model = datagen.random_a_recordset(self.zone.name) resp, resp_model = RecordsetClient.as_user('default') \ .post_recordset(self.zone.id, post_model) self.assertRaises( exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.put_recordset, self.zone.id, resp_model.id, post_model) def test_delete_fake_recordset(self): self.assertRaises( exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.delete_recordset, self.zone.id, 'junk') def test_delete_existing_recordset(self): post_model = datagen.random_a_recordset(self.zone.name) resp, resp_model = RecordsetClient.as_user('default') \ .post_recordset(self.zone.id, post_model) self.assertRaises( exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.delete_recordset, self.zone.id, resp_model.id)

puppet-openstack-integration.

commit_message:
Wait for at least one interface before node lookup

During node look up sometimes IPA sends hardware inventory information before
the interfaces are up, resulting in empty interfaces information being sent
to the conductor. This causes conductor to throw exceptions and polluting
the log until the real interfaces information is populated. This change makes
IPA to wait for at least one interface to be up before trying for node lookup.

Change-Id: Ifdb91298eaa5c725f108fa722263ed925691ecda
Closes-Bug: #1562786

commit_message:
Moving config settings to magnum.conf.j2

As per a comment from jmccrory regarding the number of
config_overrides for the Magnum role, I've moved the
configuration settings from os-magnum-install.yml to
magnum.conf.j2.  I've also removed all comments and
empty sections from magnum.conf.j2 to make things clearer.

Change-Id: I60c870b29715d68f42a10313da70bb18468e13fb

commit_message:
Correcting detail-row logic to not disrupt styling

The detail-rows on source and flavor transfer tables get styling confused
when items are selected because their detail-row elements remain and thus
confuse the alternate styling.  This patch fixes both of those tables
to exclude the detail-row when the primary row is also excluded.

Test this by (before the patch) selecting, say, the first option from the
available and see how the styling screws up on the remaining ones.  Then
apply the patch and see how everything looks beautiful.

Change-Id: Ia19fd4b47ea08c28dfb95c369b6b3f7271420f04
Closes-Bug: 1582790

commit_message:
Update to 1.9.0

Changes are:

* Add sample file generation script and helper methods
* Add equality operator to policy.RuleDefault
* Imported Translations from Zanata
* Updated from global requirements
* Fix typo: 'olso' to 'oslo'
* Add reno for release notes management
* Add policy registration and authorize method
* doc: Fix wrong import statement in usage

Change-Id: I20f9ab2ac1dd830238416c09ccfaff6b2a2f36ba

commit_message:
Document support for APC AP7921

APC's AP7921 uses the same driver as AP7922. Document this model as
being supported by the existing driver.

Change-Id: I611695e201c5df397dee24f8d270351b06efe6af

commit_message:
Replace dict.get(key) with dict[key] in unit tests

This replaces dict.get(key) with dict[key] since these are
tests and we should strive to be as clear/exact as we can.
In particular, we shouldn't be doing
    self.assertIsNone(dict.get(key))
since it will pass if 1. the value is None or 2. if the key isn't
in the dict.

Change-Id: I7b399a5f0a53f50a5ebb7febfe4f5c763bed7597
Partial-Bug: #1590808

commit_message:
Cleanup rescue images on unrescue when using RBD.

When using RBD storage driver the rescue images were previously
not removed on unrescue. Local or LVM images with suffix '.rescue'
were removed. Add the same functionality for RBD.

Change-Id: Ib44c6f8c0f19da6771914a9cdf64ac52b9bcc4ce
Closes-Bug: #1511123

commit_message:
Lowercase aggregate metadata keys due to case insensitivity

We make heavy use of the "IN" clause for updating metadata, but
MySQL treats that clause as case insensitive. This fixes an issue
where updating a key 'ABC' but already having 'abc' throws a 500
error by normalizing keys to lowercase.

Change-Id: Icebe136ead383fa7a42f0d0e876ab0cf4295361d
Related-Bug: #1538011
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/68/283868/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Make sure key is actually in our original list, # some databases have case insensitive "IN" clauses if key in all_keys: meta_ref.update({"value": metadata[key]}) already_existing_keys.add(key) # TODO(auggy): what should we do if key not in all_keys?

commit_message:
DNM: keep testing live migration despite test failures

I want to see if Jon's ceph setup fix works, so stop
exiting early if one of the runs fails some tests.

commit_message:
Set 'nested_depth=2' when calling heat.resources.list

Since Heat bug[1] have already been fixed, now we can set
'nested_depth=2' when calling heat().resources.list(), see
the TODO comment inline[2].

This is a follow up patch for patch 318416, see[3] for detail.

[1]https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1588130
[2]https://github.com/openstack/magnum/blob/678f74c12e7a0e8c8b7eaa846080426f315fac42/magnum/api/controllers/v1/bay.py#L283
[3]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/318416/

Change-Id: I7d9712510ace9de9c965d24583f8d31961114b16

commit_message:
Gate ansible-role-tripleo-* roles

* add ci script and a playbook to gate the roles
* script is compatible with future periodic and promote jobs
* add a playbook that uses the roles

Change-Id: Ib1d48d6a79ff94d2a08ea5eef12bb11cdbacf82b

added_lines: FROM {{ namespace }}/{{ image_prefix }}openstack-base:{{ tag }} MAINTAINER {{ maintainer }} {% if install_type == 'binary' %} {% if base_distro in ['fedora', 'centos', 'oraclelinux', 'rhel'] %} RUN yum -y install \ openstack-rally \ && yum clean all {% elif base_distro in ['ubuntu'] %} RUN apt-get -y install --no-install-recommends \ tempest rally \ && apt-get clean {% endif %} {% elif install_type == 'source' %} ADD rally-archive /rally-source RUN ln -s rally-source/* rally \ && /var/lib/kolla/venv/bin/pip --no-cache-dir install --upgrade -c requirements/upper-constraints.txt /rally \ && mkdir -p /etc/rally /var/log/rally {% endif %} {{ include_footer }}

commit_message:
Add downgrade migration tests

Change-Id: Idc79102273d93cd38bc1282aa003ece00ac88d63
Partial-Bug: #1391553
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/63/327063/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # coding: utf-8 # Copyright 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import datetime import alembic from nailgun.db import db from nailgun.db import dropdb from nailgun.db.migration import ALEMBIC_CONFIG from nailgun.test import base import sqlalchemy as sa _prepare_revision = '675105097a69' _test_revision = '11a9adc6d36a' def setup_module(): dropdb() alembic.command.upgrade(ALEMBIC_CONFIG, _prepare_revision) prepare() db.commit() alembic.command.downgrade(ALEMBIC_CONFIG, _test_revision) def prepare(): meta = base.reflect_db_metadata() TestNodeErrorMessageDowngrade.prepare(meta) class TestNodeErrorMessageDowngrade(base.BaseAlembicMigrationTest): node_uuid = '26b508d0-0d76-4159-bce9-f67ec2765480' long_error_msg = ''.join('a' for i in range(500)) @classmethod def prepare(cls, meta): nodes = meta.tables['nodes'] db.execute( nodes.insert(), [{ 'uuid': cls.node_uuid, 'cluster_id': None, 'group_id': None, 'status': 'discover', 'meta': '{}', 'mac': 'aa:aa:aa:aa:aa:aa', 'error_msg': cls.long_error_msg, 'timestamp': datetime.datetime.utcnow(), }] ) def test_downgrade_node_error_msg(self): nodes = self.meta.tables['nodes'] self.assertIsInstance(nodes.columns['error_msg'].type, sa.String) node = db.query(nodes).filter_by(uuid=self.node_uuid).first() self.assertEqual(node.error_msg, self.long_error_msg[:255])

commit_message:
fix sed strings in developer doc

The sample configuration file was changed so that the configuration
options are of the form 'name = value' instead of 'name=value'.

This patch updates the developer documentation [1] so that the 'sed'
instructions work properly with the new format.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/dev/dev-quickstart.html#option-1-manual-install

Change-Id: I8e36ec40c83c6d914dcd6b3d426f58415e1d3e23
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/68/327968/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sed -i "s/#auth_strategy = keystone/auth_strategy = noauth/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local sed -i "s/#enabled_drivers = pxe_ipmitool/enabled_drivers = fake_ipmitool/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local sed -i "s/#host = .*/host = test-host/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local sed -i "s/#sync_power_state_interval = 60/sync_power_state_interval = -1/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local sed -i "s/#connection = .*/connection = mysql\+pymysql:\/\/root:MYSQL_ROOT_PWD@localhost\/ironic/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local
deleted_lines: sed -i "s/#auth_strategy=keystone/auth_strategy=noauth/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local sed -i "s/#enabled_drivers=pxe_ipmitool/enabled_drivers=fake_ipmitool/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local sed -i "s/#host=.*/host=test-host/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local sed -i "s/#sync_power_state_interval=60/sync_power_state_interval=-1/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local sed -i "s/#connection=.*/connection=mysql\+pymysql:\/\/root:MYSQL_ROOT_PWD@localhost\/ironic/" etc/ironic/ironic.conf.local

subject: functions-libvirt: Issue an explicit 'restart' of libvirt daemon
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-23 10:04:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/b0b6240af2aea67010596424b6560530b29ceb79', 'message': 'functions-libvirt: Issue an explicit 'restart' of libvirt daemon

On Ubuntu Xenial, Nova live migration jobs are failing, while trying to
use the 'gate64' CPU model with errors (manually trimmed and
line-wrapped here, for brevity) like:

    "[...] 15003 ERROR nova.compute.manager [instance:
    9bc566d2-c856-4f36-bc7c-48d82870aa30] libvirtError: internal error:
    early end of file from monitor, possible problem: [...]
    qemu-system-x86_64: Unable to find CPU definition: gate64"

From testing (thanks to Clark Boylan for confirming), issuing an
explicit 'restart' (via `systemctl`) to libvirt daemon on Ubuntu Xenial
nodes brings up the 'libvirt-bin' service properly, and makes 'gate64' a
valid CPU model.

Can be tested by:

    sudo devstack/tools/cpu_map_update.py /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml
    sudo systemctl restart libvirt-bin
    sudo virsh cpu-model x86_64 | grep gate64

(Prior to an explicit restart, 'gate64' wasn't recognized as a valid CPU
model; after the restart, as above, it is.)

Change-Id: I98984f4394b57f60623339f44d9868789bad7ce8

commit_message:
functions-libvirt: Issue an explicit 'restart' of libvirt daemon

On Ubuntu Xenial, Nova live migration jobs are failing while trying to
use the 'gate64' CPU model, with this error(manually trimmed and
line-wrapped here, for brevity):

    "[...] 15003 ERROR nova.compute.manager [instance:
    9bc566d2-c856-4f36-bc7c-48d82870aa30] libvirtError: internal error:
    early end of file from monitor, possible problem: [...]
    qemu-system-x86_64: Unable to find CPU definition: gate64"

From testing (thanks to Clark Boylan for confirming), issuing an
explicit 'restart' (via `systemctl`) to libvirt daemon on Ubuntu Xenial
nodes brings up the 'libvirt-bin' service properly, and makes 'gate64' a
valid CPU model.

Can be tested by:

    sudo devstack/tools/cpu_map_update.py /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml
    sudo systemctl restart libvirt-bin
    sudo virsh cpu-model x86_64 | grep gate64

(Prior to an explicit restart, 'gate64' wasn't recognized as a valid CPU
model; after the restart, as above, it is.)

Change-Id: I98984f4394b57f60623339f44d9868789bad7ce8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/19/319819/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # libvirt to detect those changes. Use an explicit 'restart' with # `systemctl`; otherwise use 'stop'/'start' so that the new # 'cpu_map.xml' (which brings in the 'gate64' CPU model) is loaded # properly on systems like Ubuntu Trusty. if [ -x /bin/systemctl ]; then sudo /bin/systemctl restart $LIBVIRT_DAEMON else stop_service $LIBVIRT_DAEMON start_service $LIBVIRT_DAEMON fi
deleted_lines: # libvirt to detect those changes. Use a stop start as otherwise the new # cpu_map is not loaded properly on some systems (Ubuntu). stop_service $LIBVIRT_DAEMON start_service $LIBVIRT_DAEMON

The OpenStack LLC copyrights date from before OpenStack was transferred
to the foundation.

commit_message:
fix grenade from mitaka upgrade

Change-Id: I394efc93fd8943d751ece2f89608ea5b04118213
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/70/327570/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bash # ``upgrade-sahara`` function configure_sahara_upgrade { XTRACE=$(set +o | grep xtrace) set -o xtrace local old_plugins old_plugins=$(cat $SAHARA_CONF_DIR/sahara.conf | grep plugins) # resetting that to default value sed -i.bak "s/$old_plugins/plugins=fake/g" $SAHARA_CONF_DIR/sahara.conf # reset to previous state $XTRACE }

subject: Fix port range for icmp type
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-06 06:06:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/b6557b59dfbe9655a361dd855a58313ccac68ff7', 'message': 'Fix port range for ICMPv6 type

It's using "icmp6.type == { ...Type codes...}" in OVN, not
"icmp6.type >= Type-code" and "icmp6.type <= Type-code)".

But in acl_protocol_and_ports method, it's using the wrong way to
generate acl match for security group rule.

This patch tries to fix that.

Change-Id: I634095ad3a6cf1c723767ff7ea2814f692e0931e

commit_message:
Fix port range for icmp type

In method acl_protocol_and_ports method, it's using
"ICMPX.type >= Type-code" and "ICMPX.type <= Type-code", where ICMPX
could be "icmp4" or "icmp6".

But for ICMP or ICMPv6, port_range_min/max in acl_protocol_and_ports
should be considered as icmp.type and icmp.code.

This patch tries to fix that.

Closes-Bug: #1589807
Change-Id: I634095ad3a6cf1c723767ff7ea2814f692e0931e

commit_message:
Correct conditional/assignment in SolidFireDriver

In _init_volume_mappings (line 341) the conditional statement
checking the provider_id did not match the assignment four
lines later, as it does in _init_snapshot_mappings (line 323).
It has now been updated to first save the provider_id to
id_string and then use id_string in both the conditional and
assignment statements.

Change-Id: I0e6cad9fdca608e75fbb7a29e7acf446e5e7bedd
Closes-Bug: #1577459
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/41/312641/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: id_string = self._create_provider_id_string( sfvol['volumeID'], sfvol['accountID']) if v.get('provider_id', 'nil') != id_string: 'provider_id': id_string})
deleted_lines: if v.get('provider_id', 'nil') != sfvol['volumeID']: 'provider_id': self._create_provider_id_string( sfvol['volumeID'], sfvol['accountID'])})

commit_message:
Distribute PCI Requests Across Multiple Devices

PCI requests are provisioned in a list based fashion. In SR-IOV
networking devices, a set of candidate virtual functions can span
multiple physical functions and physical ports. Distributing single and
multiple device requests across multiple physical functions provides:

* Better load distribution across available links.

* Provides L2 redundancy when multiple devices are allocated on behalf
  of a single guest.

blueprint distribute-pci-allocation

Change-Id: I4af2a35de9ece709b774df9c05da33fef47157db
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/94/142094/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================================== Distribute PCI Requests Across Multiple Devices =============================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/distribute-pci-allocation.rst PCI requests are provisioned in a list based fashion. In SR-IOV networking devices, a set of candidate virtual functions can span multiple physical functions and physical ports. Distributing single and multiple device requests across multiple physical functions provides: * Better load distribution across available links. * Provides L2 redundancy when multiple devices are allocated on behalf of a single guest. Problem description =================== Simple queue based device selection for PCI SR-IOV devices does not distribute load across physical connections nor does it permit guests to achieve L2 redundancy by requesting multiple SR-IOV based ports. Use Cases ---------- Creating an Openstack instance with multiple SR-IOV ports where the ports are instantiated across diverse physical links provides more even device and link utilisation and allows guests to take advantage of L2 redundant links for bonding, etc. Project Priority ----------------- Does not directly address listed Kilo priorities. Proposed change =============== The proposed change is twofold: * Alter the PCI device request scheduling to, in the SR-IOV case, distributed PCI device requests evenly across available multiple physical functions for the same associated label. * Extend the PCI device request API to support multiple requests, signifying that the requests are on behalf of a single guest instance. This implementation supports failure if the only available virtual functions are on the same physical function. Alternatives ------------ There are no alternatives that directly satisfy distribution of requests for more even utilization. Ensuring multiple SR-IOV device requests for a guest span multiple physical links could employ additional port detail information but would still require PCI request scheduling changes. Data model impact ----------------- The current model should be sufficient as it contains the required bookkeeping. REST API impact --------------- The implementation is an internal change only and has no impact. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ There is an increase in complexity in scheduling guest creation that may increase the amount of time taken to schedule guests that are connected to multiple PCI similar SR-IOV devices. It has no effect on other cases. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Assignee: Brent Eagles Other contributors/principle reviewers: * Yongli He <yongli.he@intel.com> * Baodong (Robert) Li <baoli@cisco.com> Work Items ---------- * Alter PCI device selection logic to support distribution across multiple PCI roots (physical functions) * Extend PCI request API to support multiple device requests. * Modify scheduler code to employ the new API. * Support through 3rd party CI. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= The changes to the selection logic are testable through unit testing, as is the extension to the PCI request API. Integration and system testing will require 3rd party CI as it will require specific hardware configurations to properly test. Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ========== None.

commit_message:
spec document for sriov-physical-function-passthrough blueprint

Targeted at the Mitaka development cycle

Change-Id: Iad070a248b8f11be20f21d006a67839437f991e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/72/212472/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ Enable passthrough of SR-IOV physical functions to instances ============================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/sriov-physical-function-passthrough Nova has supported passthrough of PCI devices with it's libvirt driver for a few releases already, during which time the code has seen some stabilization and a few minor feature additions. In the case of SR-IOV enabled cards, it is possible to treat the card either as a number of virtual devices (called VFs - virtual functions) or as a full device (PF - physical function). Nova's current handling exposes only virtual functions as resources that can be requested by instances - and this is the most common use case by far. However with the rise of the requirements to virtualize network applications, it can be necessary to give instances full control over hardware and not just a single virtual function. OpenStack is seen as one of the central bits of technology for the NFV use-cases, and a lot of the work has already gone into making OpenStack and Nova NFV enabled, so we want to make sure that we close these small remaining gaps. Problem description =================== Currently it is not possible to pass through a physical function to an OpenStack instance, but some NFV applications need to have full control of the device, while others are happy with using a VF of an SR-IOV enabled card. It is beneficial to be able to do so with the same set of cards, as pre-provisioning resources on the granularity smaller than compute hosts is cumbersome to manage and goes against the goal of Nova to provide on demand resources. We want to be able to give certain instances unlimited access to the card by assigning the PF to it, but revert back to using VFs when the PF is not being used is what we would want, so as to ensure on-demand provisioning of available resources. The only driver that supports PCI pass-through (libvirt) filters out any device that is a physical function (this is hard-coded currently in the driver). In addition, modeling of PCI device resources in Nova currently assumes flat hierarchy and resource tracking logic does not understand the relationship between different PCI devices that can be exposed to Nova. Use Cases ---------- Certain NFV workloads may need to have the full control of the physical device, in order to avoid any of the VF overhead and functionality, and to be able to exclusively use the full bandwidth of the card. However, due to the dynamic nature of the elastic cloud, and the promise of Nova to we do not wish to have to pre-provision certain SR-IOV cards to be used as PFs as this defeats the promise of the infrastructure management tool that allows for quick re-purposing of resources that Nova brings. Modern SR-IOV enabled cards along with their drivers usually allow for such reconfiguration to be done on the fly, so once the passthrough of the PF is no longer needed on a specific host (either the instance using it got moved or deleted), it is expected to be able to use the VFs present on the card for new instance requests and vice versa. It is not possible to guarantee that this always works however, due to the vast range of equipment and drivers available on the market, so we want to make sure that there is a way to tell Nova that a card is in certain configuration and cannot be assumed to be reconfigurable. Project Priority ----------------- This is part of NFV enablement and thus not considered a priority. Proposed change =============== Two problems we need to solve are: 1) How to enable requesting a full physical device. This means extending the InstancePCIRequest data model to be able to hold this information. 2) Enable scheduling and resource tracking based on the request that can now be for the whole device. This means extending the data model for PCIDevices to hold information about relationship between physical and virtual functions (this relationship is already recorded but not in a suitable format), and also extending the way we expose the aggregate data about PCI devices to the resource tracker (a.k.a. the PCIDeviceStats class) to be able to present PFs and their counts, and to make sure to track the corresponding VFs that become unavailable once the PF is claimed/used. In addition to the above, it may be desirable to extend the whitelist syntax of the pci_passthrough_whitelist configuration option to enable whitelisting of VFs only, as not all SR-IOV enabled cards (and their respective drivers) enable reconfiguration such as we propose here, so we want to provide admins with the tools to do pre-provisioning if their equipment will not allow for dynamic re-assignment of functions. Alternatives ------------ There are no real alternatives that cover all of the use cases. An alternative that would cover only the requirement for bandwidth would be to allow for reserving of all VFs of a single PF by a single instance while using only a single VF, effectively reserving the bandwidth. In addition to not being a solution for all the applications, it also does not reduce the complexity of the change much as the relationship between VFs still needs to be modeled in Nova. Data model impact ----------------- Even though there is a way currently to figure out the PF a single VF belongs to (through the use of `extra_info` free-form field) it may be necessary to add a more "query friendly" relationship, that will allow us to answer the question "given a PCI device record that is a PF, which VF records does it contain". It is likely to be implemented as a foreign key relationship to the same table, and objects support will be added, but the actual implementation discussion is better suited for the actual code proposal review. REST API impact --------------- There are no API changes required. PCI devices are requested through flavor extra-specs by specifying an alias of a device specification. Currently, device specifications and their aliases are part of the Nova deployment configuration, and thus are deployment specific. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None - non-admin users will continue to use only things exposed to them via flavor extra-specs, which they cannot modify in any way. Performance Impact ------------------ Scheduling of instances requiring PCI passthrough devices will be doing more work and on a bit more data than currently in the case of PF requests. It is unlikely that this will have any noticeable performance impact however. Other deployer impact --------------------- Whitelist syntax for enabling the PCI devices will become more feature-full, due to the need to statically pre-configure certain types of cards. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Nikola Đipanov <ndipanov@redhat.com> Other contributors: Vladik Romanovsky <vromanso@redhat.com> Work Items ---------- * Re-work the DB models and corresponding objects to have explicit relationship between the PF entry and it's corresponding VFs. * Change the PCIDeviceStats class to expose PFs in it's pools, and change the claiming/consuming logic to claim appropriate amounts of VFs when a PF is consumed or claimed. * Add code to allow for filtering out the PFs (or VFs) with the whitelist config option, and remove the hard-coded check in the PCIDevTracker class. * Add support for specifying the PF requirement through the pci_alias configuration options, so that it can be requested through flavor extra-specs. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Changes proposed here only extend existing functionality, so they will require updating the current test suite to make sure new functionality is covered. It is expected that the tests currently in place are to prevent any regression to the existing functionality. No new test suites are required to be added for this functionality, only new test cases. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation for the PCI passthrough features in Nova will need to be updated to reflect the above changes - that is to say - no impact out of the ordinary. References ========== History ======= Optional section for Mitaka intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time. .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

commit_message:
Update tests of YAQL queries

Adds tests for initial value of sum() method.
Adds tests for isIterable() method.
Renames test_split to test_split_where.

Change-Id: I898f78481b5d88018b1c9916dbb012c1e4b5e87c

commit_message:
Relax the project name uniqueness constraints

Relax the current restriction that a project name must be unique in a domain
(and hence within a project hierarchy), replacing it with simply being unique
within it's parent.

This is intended as an alternative to
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/318605/, only one of these two
will be implemented.

Implements blueprint: project-name-relax
Change-Id: Id5931f8f3a73a3cbe09d43dc35b72b204590017c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/48/310048/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== Optionally enforce URL-safe domain and project names ==================================================== `bp project-name-relax <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/project-name-relax>`_ Relax the current restriction that a project name must be unique in a domain (and hence within a project hierarchy), replacing it with simply being unique within it's parent. Problem Description =================== Due to our heritage of a flat tenant model, a project's name must be unique within a domain, regardless of where that project sits in any project hierarchy within that domain. As project hierarchies grow, this will become increasingly untenable. One of the reasons this could not be relaxed before was that there would be no way of reliably addressing a project by name within a hierarchy. Proposed Change =============== In Mitaka, we laid the ground work for allowing the specification of a non-unique project name in an API request, by supporting an optional ability to make sure project names are url safe [1]. Deployments that are running with this feature enabled could reliably use a url naming scheme to address a project, if we were to provide one, for example:: :: { "auth": { "identity": { ... }, "scope": { "project": { "domain": { "name": "acme.com" }, "name": "development/sas/myproject" } } } } It is proposed that we now enable this capability, and at the same time relax the naming restrictions of projects, such that their names only need to be unique within their parent. This will be optional, controlled by a configuration option, which by default is disabled. In order for this option to be honored, the deployment must be running with url_safe project naming set to `strict`. In addition to the auth block, the project name query parameter for list projects will also allow a url-style project name to be specified. The V2 API list tenants by tenant name will not support the new capability. The check to ensure that the url_safe naming is set to `strict` and that the ability to use url-style naming is also enabled, will be made at run-time every time the project name needs to be processed in the auth or project list APIs. If either these are disabled, then the name specified will be treated as simple project name, without any attempt to process the separator characters. Although ideally once enabled, such configuration options would never be disabled - it is not practical for us to enforce this. It would be possible, therefore, for deployer to create some projects with non domain-wide unique names, then disable the feature and no longer be able to address some of those projects by name. To aid this situation, an option will be added to keystone-manage that will list any projects that have non-unique names within a domain. To be clear, this proposal does not cause the project name stored in the SQL database to be changed. Rather, it simply allows the specification of a url-style string for a project name in the API. The separator used in such url-style naming will be the forward slash character `/`. It would be possible to make the separator configurable by deployment via a configuration option - however the confusion of having to know the separator for a given cloud (before you authenticate), seems to create a worse problem than simply having a fixed separator in the first place, so it is proposed that we do not allow the separator to be modified. Alternatives ------------ None Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- See Identity specification changes proposed as part of this patch. Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: henry-nash Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None, above and beyond unit testing Documentation Impact ==================== Changes to the Identity API to clarify naming. References ========== [1] `url-safe-names <https://github.com/openstack/keystone-specs/blob/master/specs/keystone/mitaka/url-safe-names.rst>_`.

commit_message:
Consolidate trust tests into a single class

Previously, all the trust auth tests were seperated into different test
classes. This consolidates the trust tests to be contained within one class
that details all the trust behavior. This makes it easier to run all the trust
tests against different keystone configurations.

Change-Id: Icb2abd082ffd3ab7d86a49255da8405a59e074a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/52/266052/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class TrustAPIBehavior(test_v3.RestfulTestCase): super(TrustAPIBehavior, self).config_overrides() def setup_trust_chain(self): # Create trust chain self.user_chain = list() self.trust_chain = list() for _ in range(3): user = unit.create_user(self.identity_api, domain_id=self.domain_id) self.user_chain.append(user) # trustor->trustee trustee = self.user_chain[0] trust_ref = unit.new_trust_ref( trustor_user_id=self.user_id, trustee_user_id=trustee['id'], project_id=self.project_id, impersonation=True, expires=dict(minutes=1), role_ids=[self.role_id]) trust_ref.update( allow_redelegation=True, redelegation_count=3) r = self.post('/OS-TRUST/trusts', body={'trust': trust_ref}) trust = self.assertValidTrustResponse(r) auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=trustee['id'], password=trustee['password'], trust_id=trust['id']) trust_token = self.get_requested_token(auth_data) self.trust_chain.append(trust) for trustee in self.user_chain[1:]: trust_ref = unit.new_trust_ref( trustor_user_id=self.user_id, trustee_user_id=trustee['id'], project_id=self.project_id, impersonation=True, role_ids=[self.role_id]) trust_ref.update( allow_redelegation=True) r = self.post('/OS-TRUST/trusts', body={'trust': trust_ref}, token=trust_token) trust = self.assertValidTrustResponse(r) auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=trustee['id'], password=trustee['password'], trust_id=trust['id']) trust_token = self.get_requested_token(auth_data) self.trust_chain.append(trust) trustee = self.user_chain[-1] trust = self.trust_chain[-1] auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=trustee['id'], password=trustee['password'], trust_id=trust['id']) self.last_token = self.get_requested_token(auth_data) def setUp(self): super(TrustAPIBehavior, self).setUp() # create a trustee to delegate stuff to self.trustee_user_id = self.trustee_user['id'] self.setup_trust_chain() # testing utility methods specific to trusts def assert_user_authenticate(self, user): auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=user['id'], password=user['password'] ) r = self.v3_create_token(auth_data) self.assertValidTokenResponse(r) def assertTrustTokensRevoked(self, trust_id): revocation_response = self.get('/OS-REVOKE/events') revocation_events = revocation_response.json_body['events'] found = False for event in revocation_events: if event.get('OS-TRUST:trust_id') == trust_id: found = True self.assertTrue(found, 'event with trust_id %s not found in list' % trust_id) def assert_trust_tokens_revoked(self, trust_id): trustee = self.user_chain[0] auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=trustee['id'], password=trustee['password'] ) r = self.v3_create_token(auth_data) self.assertValidTokenResponse(r) revocation_response = self.get('/OS-REVOKE/events') revocation_events = revocation_response.json_body['events'] found = False for event in revocation_events: if event.get('OS-TRUST:trust_id') == trust_id: found = True self.assertTrue(found, 'event with trust_id %s not found in list' % trust_id) # testing for redelegation scenarios # trust chaining test cases # trust authentication test cases self.user['enabled'] = False self.identity_api.update_user(self.user['id'], self.user) self.trustee_user['enabled'] = False self.identity_api.update_user(self.trustee_user['id'], self.trustee_user)
deleted_lines: class TestTrustRedelegation(test_v3.RestfulTestCase): """Redelegation valid and secure Redelegation is a hierarchical structure of trusts between initial trustor and a group of users allowed to impersonate trustor and act in his name. Hierarchy is created in a process of trusting already trusted permissions and organized as an adjacency list using 'redelegated_trust_id' field. Redelegation is valid if each subsequent trust in a chain passes 'not more' permissions than being redelegated. Trust constraints are: * roles - set of roles trusted by trustor * expiration_time * allow_redelegation - a flag * redelegation_count - decreasing value restricting length of trust chain * remaining_uses - DISALLOWED when allow_redelegation == True Trust becomes invalid in case: * trust roles were revoked from trustor * one of the users in the delegation chain was disabled or deleted * expiration time passed * one of the parent trusts has become invalid * one of the parent trusts was deleted """ super(TestTrustRedelegation, self).config_overrides() enabled=True, def setUp(self):
